## Basic concepts

We are going to go through some basic models for population growth, in which age and most other features of real populations are disregarded

::: {.fragment .fade-in}
A population count at time $t$ is denoted by $P_t$ when we use discrete values, or $P(t)$ over a continuum of time
:::


::: {.fragment .fade-in}

::: {.column-width="60%"}
Let's use a population of 100 rabbits as an example and their rate of growth is 10% per year
:::

:::{.column-width="40%"}
![](images/rabbits.jpg){.lightbox fig-align="center" width="50%"}
:::

:::

::: {.fragment .fade-in}
So $P(t_0) = 100$, $r=.1$ and $P(0)=0$
:::


## Linear growth
::: incremental
Let's say the population of rabbits grows  linearly
That means that in a linear expression $y = a+b*x$ we can describe as $P(t)=P(t_0)+r*(t-t_0)$
So, what do we know so far?
$$
P(t)=100+1.1*(t-t_0)
$$
Then, we get a plot that looks like this
```{r}
library(tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)
t <- data.frame(t= c(0,1,2,3,4,5,10,20,50,100))
p0 <- 4

linear_g <- function(t,r){
  a <- p0
  result <- a+(r+1)*t
  return(result)
}

t_linear <- t |> 
  mutate(P = linear_g(t=t, r=1.1))

p_linear <- ggplot(data = t_linear, 
       aes(x=t, y=P))+
  geom_line()
```
:::

## Exponential growth
- We assume population increases without limitations along time
- J-shaped curve (as the $(x)$ function)
```{r}

exponential_g <- function(t,r){
  p0 <- 100
  r <- 1+r
  result <- p0*r^t
  return(result)
}

t_exponential <- t |> 
  mutate(P=exponential_g(t=t, r=.1))


```

## Logistic growth
- We put a limit to the logistic growth because environmental, resources and predators could constrinct that growth
```{r}
logistic_g <- function(t,r,a){
  numerator <- a
  denominator <- 1+exp((-r)*(t))
}
```
